SC Starts Conduct Purge Frosh Popularity Contest Begins;
After Digging Up Powers Seven Top Jobs On The Block
The Student Council this week
took steps to assert its own
la tent authority in Matters of
non-academic honor at Hopkins.
Brought to a head by criticism
of the Council's inaction following recent bad conduct at
Hopkins events and by the unearthin of several
SC resolutions
Passed two years ago, Council
President Charlie Ginsberg appointed a new standing committee which will review future
ungentlemanly conduct and decide
whether it necessitates a hearing
by the Student
Council.
The new committee, which will
act "in a judicial capacity," is
composed of Council President
Ginsberg, SAC President Dick
Einaugler and senior representatives Chuck
Loughran, Dave
Meredith and Erv Sekulow. It is
Probable that future committees
Will involve
those who hold these
same positions on
the Council.
Eureka!
At Tuesday's SC meeting in
Levering Hall, Ginsberg read
from the Dec.
7, 1956 issue of
the NewsLetter an article which
listed four newly-passed council
resolutions. These
in effect
warned
against ungentlemanly
conduct at any Hopkins activity,
DIAMONDS

;ye
'00

made any individual found
guilty of damaging property
financially responsible for such
damage and threatened annihilation of any organization which
failed to work in conjunction
with the Gentleman's Code Committee to prevent misdemeanors.
The article included a statement by Code Committee chairman Erv Sekulow that these resolutions "in no way provided
for a trial panel to try non-academic violations, because it is
hoped that Hopkins men will be
able to accept the responsibility
of a community of gentlemen."
Sekulow this week said he feels
the council as a whole should
have "hearing rather than
trials."

Power To Destroy
The sentiment that "we (the
SC) can declare any activity inactive" was still prevalent at
Tuesday's meeting.
It was made clear that unless
an individual is found to be
guilty of disorderly conduct at a
Hopkins event, the group sponsoring the event "would have to
pay any damages even if this

group feels it couldn't possibly
have stopped the damage."
At this point in the discussion
a judicial committee was suggested "to fill a vacuum existing
in the Council setup."

Native Intelligence?
The suggestion included

a
statement that the committee
should decide if conduct in a
certain case should be deemed as
ungentlemanly and should recommend such conduct for a
Council hearing upon the committee's own decision.
The spokesman spoke against
those asking for a definition of
what constitutes "ungentlemanly
conduct" by saying: "I think we
can consider the committee
members capable of a little native intelligence. Surely we can't
issue an edict on a whole body of
laws for the Homewood."
When several members of the
Council asked for a vote on the
formation of such a committee,
Ginsberg assumed responsibility
by saying: "It is the president's
prerogative to appoint any committee he desires." "We've got to
start somewhere," someone was
heard to mumble.

This week freshman elections
got off to a roaring start as the
candidates for the offices of
president, vice-president, secretary, treasurer and the three
student council reps got up their
petitions.

Time is running out, but students interested in running for
an office may pick up petitions
at the SAC office at the barn
from 12 to 1 o'clock today. All
petitions must be submitted by
Tuesday, December 2. All candidates with 40 or more names on
their petitions will have their
names placed on the primary
ballots.
-

Thursday and Friday, December 4 and 5, are the days of
reckoning for the petitioners. On
these days ballots for the primary election may be turned in
from 9 to 4 o'clock in Gilman
Hall across from the. post office
and from 5 to 6 o'clock in the
dorms. The two receiving the
most votes for each office will
have their names placed on the
final ballot. In case of a tie,
three names will be placed on
the final ballot.
The final elections will be held
Tuesday and Wednesday, December 9 and 10. A plurality will
be all that is necessary to win
election of an office.

In an exclusive interview conducted in a secret chamber deep
within the confines of the barn
this week, Douglas Radcliff Urnstead, a sophomore in the Romance Languages Department,
revealed the secrets of his
clandestine life. Here, for the
first time in print, the NewsLetter will expose the deep dark
secrets of the secret life of the
self-styled "Baron •of Pigtown".
Far from being an international playboy, the Baron suggested that he is a cross between
Alfred E. Neumann and Charlie
Brown. He put it this way—"I
am a Neo-Deist, and, as a NeoDeist, I believe that there exists
in every individual the essence
of an etherial force. Now each
individual must seek into himself to identify himself with this
essence; this is the existentialist
theory that there can be no organization in the community because the force of the community
can destroy the individual."
Mr. Umstead's conflict' with
society seems quite evident.
When asked where he could be
found on campus, he replied,
"When I am not in my locker
or my briefcase, you can find me
in the Goodwillie Room."
With this the conversation
took a new twist—the enormous
briefcase of Mr. Umstead.
Reputed to weigh as much as

25 pounds on a rainy day, this
monstrous leather briefcase is a
carry-all for the ideas of the
Baron who claims he himself
2 pounds—on
dresses out at 82 1'
a rainy day.
"What do you keep in your big
briefcase?" we asked the little
man. "Why—a little woman of
course," he replied, innocently
tightening his belt.
"Rumor has it that you store
volumes of pornography in your
briefcase," we remarked. "Certainly not!" said the Baron. The
question, "Where then do you
keep your pornography?" followed. An obviously indignant
Umstead answered "Sketches of
nude women are not Pornography."
Leaving what seemed to be a
sore subject with Mr. U. we
delved deeper into his cavernous
carry-all.
In addition to various hi-fl
selections, several Italian novels,
three old copies of the NewsLetter, we found a portable easel,
and several tubes of dried up and

As a poet and a writer, the
Baron has received several national awards. He keeps a huge
notebook within his briefcase in
which he jots down ideas and
other material for his future
works. Included in these notes
are the plans for his first novel,
"The Days: The Nights: The
Passions." He stresses that passion in this case is in the strict
classical sense. Also it is important to note that Umstead IS
essentially "a traveling artist."

Strong photographs the atmosphere of Mars.
Their sky observatory—which
would allow sightings above almost all the earth's atmospheric
haze—has never been tried before.
Just Plain Bill
Strong, who calls himself
merely a gadgeteer, sees this system as a potentially significant
addition to space study tools. It
Would allow viewing from high
enough "that the stars no longer
twinkle"; it would make possible
daytime viewing of Mercury, a
planet hard to see at night, and
would make possible infra-red
ray studies difficult on earth because its water vapor blocks the
rays.
He sees the system as a step
toward a manned observatory
orbiting in space. He said their
gondola could be mounted with

little change on the nose of a
rocket and shot into space.
However, the Hopkins professor on June 9, did conquer the
first of two most important problems in his projected balloon
flight to 80,000 feet to study
the water vapor on Mars.
His newly designed telescope
was lifted from the trailer, in
which it was transported from
Ames Hall on the Hopkins
campus to the Strato-Bowl
twelve miles south Qf Rapid City.
The telescope was successfully
lowered through a top hatch of
the gondola and bolted to the
floor of the gondola. Protruding
from the top of the gondola is
the other half of the telescope
where it will encounter a temperature of 65 degrees below
zero at top altitude.

Big Brother Speaks
To the Editors:
This is the biggest weekend of
the fall and I would like to remind the students of their obligation to the university and
themselves. I realize that the
athletes will- have finished their
seasons and that the H-Club
dance has in the past been noted
for its drinking, but now the students and their ability to behave
in a mature manner without administrative restrictions are on
trial.
Any flagrant niiSconduct will
necessarily, therefore, be dealt
with by the Student Council in
the best interests of the University, the H-Club, and the other
students. If the dance should
get out of control, it will be
stopped not only for this year
but also possibly for future
years.
I would like to ask the students to please keep this in mind
not only for their own pleasure
but for that of the others.
Charlie Ginsberg
President, Student Council

to examine a number of interesting gift suggestions.
We will Start with the hardest gift problem of all: What do
You give to the person who has everything? Well sir, there follows a list of a half dozen gifts which.I will flatly guarantee the
Person who has everything does not have:
I. A dentist's chair.
• 2. A low hurdle.
3. A street map of Perth.

5. A carton of filter-tip Marlboros.
6. A carton of non-filter Philip Morris.
"What?" you exclaim, your young eyebrows rising in wild
incredulity. "The person who has everything does not have
cartons of filter Marlboros and non-filter Philip Morris?" you
Shriek, your young lips curling mockingly. "What arrant nonsense!" you rasp, making a coarse gesture.
And I reply with an emphatic no! The person who has everything does not have filter Marlboros and non-filter Philip Morris";

Morris and if lie is a person who likes a mild, mellow, fresh,
flavorful cigarette—and who does not? eh? who does not?—

smokes them. He might possibly have a large collection of
Marlboro and Philip Morris butts, but whole Marlboros and
Philip Morris? No. An emphatic no!

Hopkins freedoms has disappeared. Recently a manifestation of exuberance on the part

dd'rmitory house well-known for

student control of it, and set up

(Continued from page 7)
and his technical crew have been
working on the telescope every
night, testing every detail of this
complex telescope to assure
tl--nnselves that it can do the
job for which it will be launched.
Critical Step
On November 8 Dr. Strong
was willing to have it moved
from the trailer. At ten a.m, a
crew lowered a wooden cradle
into the trailer from the giant
hook of a fifty foot crane. When
the cradle was securely bound to
the telescope, the crane operator
started to pull the telescope upward, inch by inch. A half hour
later the telescope was swung
free of the trailer and slowly
moved over fifteen feet where
it hung directly over the top
hatch of the gondola.
Foul* technicians stood on a
wooden platform surrounding
the gondola guiding the tubular
end of the telescope as it was
again inch by inch lowered into
the gondola. Three men were
Inside the gondola to guide it to
fts lower mounting as it slipped
lower toward the gondola floor.

HELD OVER!

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOV. 21, 1958 Ho

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE FOURTEEN

As still' cameramen, motion
picture operators and newsmen
recorded the action they joined
the technical crew in hardly
breathing while this, one of the
most important pre-flight activities took place. Dr. Strong stood
by in his flaming red wool shirt,
pulling on his ever-present pipe,
watching expressionless as the
telescope was moved.
One strong jerk by the crane,
or the breaking of any part
of the cradle could have spelled
disaster for this historic project.
One can call this a truly historic flight because it will be
the first time a human being
has risen to a height where he
is above 97% of the earth's atmosphere to get an unobstructed
view of a planet. Dr. Strong said
today that if successful he will
see Mars better than he could
with the 200-inch telescope at
Mt. Palomar.

At 12:35 the telescope was
bolted to the floor of the gondola—safely.
During the next few days Di.
Strong will test the telescope
from within the gondola; will
spend two seven hour periods inside the gondola with Commander Malcolm D. Ross from whom
Strong will receive indoctrination in everything to be done
during the flight. Commander
Ross'is one of the world's best
balloon pilots, having made three
record breaking ascents in this
gondola, which was originally
designed in 1946 by Jean Piccard, brother of Auguste Piccard
who made the first flight into
the stratosphere.
Thin Yellow Suits Supplied
While
being
indoctrinated
both Strong and Ross will wear
their pressure suits, pressurized
masks and helmets. Over the

pressure suit they will wear arctic
weather jackets and another suit
of thin, yellow material. At top
altitude during the night of the
flight the temperature inside the
gondola will be aproximately 20
degrees above zero, and may
drop lower.
Today Commander Ross said
they will take coffee, water,
candy bars, and sandwiches
wrapped in sealed plastic containers for food on this 24-hour

• At 2:00 p.m. they will be taken
to the gondola where they will
sit on the nylon webbing seats
and begin their pre-flight operations. At 2:15 p.m. the entrance
hatch will be sealed from within
the gondola.
At one p.m. the 300-ft.-long
plastic balloon will begin to he
inflated from long helium tanks.
By 3 p.m. the balloon should be
one-fifth inflated. Full inflation
will take place as the helium
expands during the ascent to
80,000 feet. At top altitude the
balloon will expand to 2-million
cubic feet, an a diameter of
173 feet.
Set Free
At approximately 3:15 the balloon will be set free from the
floor 500 feet below the rim of
the Strato-Bowl.
If good winds prevail the
balloon and gondola should land
somewhere within a 200 mile
radius of Chicago.

Electrodes Too!
On launch day Strong and
Ross will be taken to a readyshack at approximately 1:00 p.m.
wheer Captain Norman L. Barr,
medical director for the flight,
will tape electrodes to various
parts of their bodies. These
electrodes will be plugged into a
tiny radio sending set, the size
of a package of cigarettes. This
will send back to Dr. Barr, flying in his airplane, information
on the rate of their breathing,
heart beat, skin temperature and
several other bits of information about their reaction. After
this they will don their flying
gear.

The launch was expected to
have taken place on Thursdah
November 13, weather permitting. Sunny skies and no breeze
were needed for a perfect launch.

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE EIGHTEEN

Jay Junior Jocks Dribblers Make Beall
Cap Grid Careers For Towson Opening
By JOE FERRANTE
The Johns Hopkins freshman
football squad closed out a
"highly successful season" last
week, finishing the season at
Gettysburg with a 3-1 record.
Coach Bob Scott lauded his
boys, saying, "This team accomplished more with its physical ability than any other frosh
team I've ever handled here.
Despite its limited experience,
only 17 of the 36 on the team
had ever played before, the team
really came through."
At Gettysburg, the junior Birdmen displayed an excellent team
effort against a school whose
football is in a bit faster league
than is Hopkins.
The Jays dominated play for
most of the first half, taking an
8-0 lead, with their score coming
on a. three yard plunge by fullback Phil Sutley, whose rushing,
93 yards on 21 carries, kept the
offense moving. The extra points
were added by virtue of a Powellto-Sutley pass.Gettysburg evened
the score in the last 45 seconds
of the half on a fourteen yard
TD-pass.
Impressive Stands
During the second half, the
Gettysburg team controlled the
ball most of the time, but were
held from scoring by two impressive goal-line stands on the part
of the Hopkins defensive line..
After the second stand, the
Blue Jay frosh began to move
with the ball. Highlighted by the
brutal running of Sutley, the
Jays brought the ball to their
30-yard line. There they fumbled. G-Burg took the pigskin
and, after three unsuccessful
scoring attempts, hit pay dirt
with a fourth down pass. The
conversion was missed.
Desperation passes by the Blue
Jay frosh were to no avail, and
the clock ran out with the score
at 14-8, in favor of Gettysburg.
As far as the season's performance is concerned, the team
received good mileage from quarterbacks Billy Powell and Joe
Cioni, halfbacks Henry Ciccarone
and Bill Flannery and, fullbacks
Bob Homlar and Phil Sutley,
Statistics And Squad
Ciccarone, Flannery, Homlar
and Sutley each averaged over

we've

3.5 yards a carry on the ground.
Cioni, Powell, and Ciccarone
sparked the passing offense, with
Ciccarone tossing three TD passes, of 35, 46 and 46 yards, to end
Terry Weltman. Cioni and Powell threw several passes to end
Jerry Schmidt for large gains.
Rounding out the backfield
were Don Layne, Derwin Kim,
Joe Dornbush, Tim Parmley,
Frank Hussey, Don Haynie and
Roland Blantz,
Coach Scott had great praise
for his defensive line, which held
the opposition to an average of
80 yards rushing per game. The
line was mainly composed of ends
Weltman and Schmidt; tackles
John Becker, Buff Ward and
John Doud; guards Dale Steiger,
Dave Rowe and Dick Hoover and
center Pat Boyer.
Backing up the starting ends
were Roger Peterson, George
Zaiser, Bob Raub and Al Shevach. Completing the tackle
corps were Don- Steiner, Bill
Westerkam and Stan Levine.
"Valuable Addition"
Other guards who saw action
were Jon Hayes, the team's punting specialist who averaged 39.5
yards on ten punts, Ted Hartka,
Lee Hollein, Dick King, Doug
Kushnir and Roy Mayne. Lou
Svoboda, who subbed at center,
also showed much improvement.
Coach Scott emphasized that
Duane Levine, a chemical engineering grad student and former Hopkins player, who was responsible for the backfield play,
was a "great help to me and the
team." Also, George Cooke, Wilfred Fujimoto, and Clarence Nagao, managers, gave the team a
hard working staff.
In summing up his views on
this year's frosh football squad,
the coach stated that "they will
be a valuable addition to the
varsity squad next Year. I feel
sure that they will be able to
make the switch to single-wing
play."

the team's performance.

H. James Cornelius graduated from
Swarthmore College in 1954 with a B.S.
in Electrical Engineering: He's been
"growing" ever since with the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania.
After an initial 44-week inter-departmental training course, Jim was made
Facility Engineer in charge of the fastgrowing Norristown-Pottstown area. In
that capacity, he engineered over half a
million dollars' worth of carrier systems
and cable facilities between major switching centers.
Today, he is one of 50 young engineers
from the Bell Telephone Companies
chosen to attend a special Operating
Engineers Training Program at Bell Lab-

oratories. This 19-month course of study
—with full pay—deals with advanced
techniques and new concepts in electronics which signal a-new era in telephony. It involves both classroom theory
and practical laboratory applications.
When Jim and his colleagues return to
their companies, they'll review major
engineering projects. This will assure
the best use of equipment for current
engineering, as well as for expected new
developments in communications.
"I wanted a job I could grow with,"
says Jim, "and I've got it. I can't think
of a better place than the telephone company for an engineering graduate to find
a promising future."

Many young men like Jim Cornelius are finding rewarding careers with the Bell Telephone Companies.

interviewer when he visits your campus. And read the
Bell Telephone booklet on file in your Placement Office.

Blue Jays journey to Westminster tomorrow seeking a fourth
consecutive conquest of their
arch rival. Should the Jays be
successful in their encounter
with the Green Terrors, they
will gain the championship of

SC Starts Conduct Purge Frosh Popularity Contest Begins;
After Digging Up Powers Seven Top Jobs On The Block
The Student Council this week
took steps to assert its own
la tent authority in Matters of
non-academic honor at Hopkins.
Brought to a head by criticism
of the Council's inaction following recent bad conduct at
Hopkins events and by the unearthin of several
SC resolutions
Passed two years ago, Council
President Charlie Ginsberg appointed a new standing committee which will review future
ungentlemanly conduct and decide
whether it necessitates a hearing
by the Student
Council.
The new committee, which will
act "in a judicial capacity," is
composed of Council President
Ginsberg, SAC President Dick
Einaugler and senior representatives Chuck
Loughran, Dave
Meredith and Erv Sekulow. It is
Probable that future committees
Will involve
those who hold these
same positions on
the Council.
Eureka!
At Tuesday's SC meeting in
Levering Hall, Ginsberg read
from the Dec.
7, 1956 issue of
the NewsLetter an article which
listed four newly-passed council
resolutions. These
in effect
warned
against ungentlemanly
conduct at any Hopkins activity,
DIAMONDS

;ye
'00

made any individual found
guilty of damaging property
financially responsible for such
damage and threatened annihilation of any organization which
failed to work in conjunction
with the Gentleman's Code Committee to prevent misdemeanors.
The article included a statement by Code Committee chairman Erv Sekulow that these resolutions "in no way provided
for a trial panel to try non-academic violations, because it is
hoped that Hopkins men will be
able to accept the responsibility
of a community of gentlemen."
Sekulow this week said he feels
the council as a whole should
have "hearing rather than
trials."

Power To Destroy
The sentiment that "we (the
SC) can declare any activity inactive" was still prevalent at
Tuesday's meeting.
It was made clear that unless
an individual is found to be
guilty of disorderly conduct at a
Hopkins event, the group sponsoring the event "would have to
pay any damages even if this

group feels it couldn't possibly
have stopped the damage."
At this point in the discussion
a judicial committee was suggested "to fill a vacuum existing
in the Council setup."

Native Intelligence?
The suggestion included

a
statement that the committee
should decide if conduct in a
certain case should be deemed as
ungentlemanly and should recommend such conduct for a
Council hearing upon the committee's own decision.
The spokesman spoke against
those asking for a definition of
what constitutes "ungentlemanly
conduct" by saying: "I think we
can consider the committee
members capable of a little native intelligence. Surely we can't
issue an edict on a whole body of
laws for the Homewood."
When several members of the
Council asked for a vote on the
formation of such a committee,
Ginsberg assumed responsibility
by saying: "It is the president's
prerogative to appoint any committee he desires." "We've got to
start somewhere," someone was
heard to mumble.

This week freshman elections
got off to a roaring start as the
candidates for the offices of
president, vice-president, secretary, treasurer and the three
student council reps got up their
petitions.

Time is running out, but students interested in running for
an office may pick up petitions
at the SAC office at the barn
from 12 to 1 o'clock today. All
petitions must be submitted by
Tuesday, December 2. All candidates with 40 or more names on
their petitions will have their
names placed on the primary
ballots.
-

Thursday and Friday, December 4 and 5, are the days of
reckoning for the petitioners. On
these days ballots for the primary election may be turned in
from 9 to 4 o'clock in Gilman
Hall across from the. post office
and from 5 to 6 o'clock in the
dorms. The two receiving the
most votes for each office will
have their names placed on the
final ballot. In case of a tie,
three names will be placed on
the final ballot.
The final elections will be held
Tuesday and Wednesday, December 9 and 10. A plurality will
be all that is necessary to win
election of an office.

In an exclusive interview conducted in a secret chamber deep
within the confines of the barn
this week, Douglas Radcliff Urnstead, a sophomore in the Romance Languages Department,
revealed the secrets of his
clandestine life. Here, for the
first time in print, the NewsLetter will expose the deep dark
secrets of the secret life of the
self-styled "Baron •of Pigtown".
Far from being an international playboy, the Baron suggested that he is a cross between
Alfred E. Neumann and Charlie
Brown. He put it this way—"I
am a Neo-Deist, and, as a NeoDeist, I believe that there exists
in every individual the essence
of an etherial force. Now each
individual must seek into himself to identify himself with this
essence; this is the existentialist
theory that there can be no organization in the community because the force of the community
can destroy the individual."
Mr. Umstead's conflict' with
society seems quite evident.
When asked where he could be
found on campus, he replied,
"When I am not in my locker
or my briefcase, you can find me
in the Goodwillie Room."
With this the conversation
took a new twist—the enormous
briefcase of Mr. Umstead.
Reputed to weigh as much as

25 pounds on a rainy day, this
monstrous leather briefcase is a
carry-all for the ideas of the
Baron who claims he himself
2 pounds—on
dresses out at 82 1'
a rainy day.
"What do you keep in your big
briefcase?" we asked the little
man. "Why—a little woman of
course," he replied, innocently
tightening his belt.
"Rumor has it that you store
volumes of pornography in your
briefcase," we remarked. "Certainly not!" said the Baron. The
question, "Where then do you
keep your pornography?" followed. An obviously indignant
Umstead answered "Sketches of
nude women are not Pornography."
Leaving what seemed to be a
sore subject with Mr. U. we
delved deeper into his cavernous
carry-all.
In addition to various hi-fl
selections, several Italian novels,
three old copies of the NewsLetter, we found a portable easel,

other material for his future
works. Included in these notes
are the plans for his first novel,
"The Days: The Nights: The
Passions." He stresses that passion in this case is in the strict
classical sense. Also it is important to note that Umstead IS

would allow sightings above almost all the earth's atmospheric
haze—has never been tried before.
Just Plain Bill
Strong, who calls himself
merely a gadgeteer, sees this system as a potentially significant
addition to space study tools. It
Would allow viewing from high
enough "that the stars no longer
twinkle"; it would make possible
daytime viewing of Mercury, a
planet hard to see at night, and
would make possible infra-red
ray studies difficult on earth because its water vapor blocks the
rays.
He sees the system as a step
toward a manned observatory
orbiting in space. He said their
gondola could be mounted with

little change on the nose of a
rocket and shot into space.
However, the Hopkins professor on June 9, did conquer the
first of two most important problems in his projected balloon
flight to 80,000 feet to study
the water vapor on Mars.
His newly designed telescope
was lifted from the trailer, in
which it was transported from

campus to the Strato-Bowl
twelve miles south Qf Rapid City.
The telescope was successfully
lowered through a top hatch of
the gondola and bolted to the
floor of the gondola. Protruding
from the top of the gondola is
the other half of the telescope
where it will encounter a temperature of 65 degrees below
zero at top altitude.

LETTERS
Big Brother Speaks
To the Editors:
This is the biggest weekend of
the fall and I would like to remind the students of their obligation to the university and
themselves. I realize that the
athletes will- have finished their
seasons and that the H-Club
dance has in the past been noted
for its drinking, but now the students and their ability to behave
in a mature manner without administrative restrictions are on
trial.
Any flagrant niiSconduct will
necessarily, therefore, be dealt
with by the Student Council in
the best interests of the University, the H-Club, and the other
students. If the dance should
get out of control, it will be
stopped not only for this year
but also possibly for future
years.
I would like to ask the students to please keep this in mind
not only for their own pleasure
but for that of the others.
Charlie Ginsberg
President, Student Council

night crawlers—but let me interrupt your multifarious activities—studying, going to class, helping old grads find their
dentures after Homecoming—to remind you that busy as you
are—studying, going to class, searching for meat in the dormitory stew—time and tide wait for no man,and the Yuletide will
soon be upon us. Busy or not, we must turn our thoughts to
Christma.s shopping. Let us,'therefore, pause for a moment in
our busy schedules—studying, going to class, rolling drunks—
to examine a number of interesting gift suggestions.
We will Start with the hardest gift problem of all: What do
You give to the person who has everything? Well sir, there follows a list of a half dozen gifts which.I will flatly guarantee the
Person who has everything does not have:
I. A dentist's chair.
• 2. A low hurdle.
3. A street map of Perth.
• 4. Fifty pounds of chicken fat.
5. A carton of filter-tip Marlboros.
6. A carton of non-filter Philip Morris.
"What?" you exclaim, your young eyebrows rising in wild
incredulity. "The person who has everything does not have
cartons of filter Marlboros and non-filter Philip Morris?" you
Shriek, your young lips curling mockingly. "What arrant nonsense!" you rasp, making a coarse gesture.
And I reply with an emphatic no! The person who has everything does not have filter Marlboros and non-filter Philip Morris";
—not for long anyhow—because if he has Marlboros and Philip
Morris and if lie is a person who likes a mild, mellow, fresh,
flavorful cigarette—and who does not? eh? who does not?—
why, then he doesn't have Marlboros and Philip Morris; he
smokes them. He might possibly have a large collection of
Marlboro and Philip Morris butts, but whole Marlboros and
Philip Morris? No. An emphatic no!
Nc'w we take up another thorny gift problem: What do you
buy Your girl if you are broke? Quite a challenge, you will agree,
hut there is an answer—nn ingenious, exciting answer! Surprise
Your girl with a beautiful bronze head of herself

Squealer
To the Editors:
Another of the much-vaunted
Hopkins freedoms has disappeared. Recently a manifestation of exuberance on the part
of a number of students in a
dd'rmitory house well-known for
its entry spirit caused annoyance to two of the self-appointed guardians of the Hopkins
morals. These two conspirators,
disdaining the normal procedure
for complaint, took it upon themselves to give their version of the
story directly to the D.S.R.C.
president, without even consulting the house represefitative.
That these had some right to
complain is not denied by any;
but there is a system for corn
plaining which is very clearly
delineated in the D.S.R.C. Constitution. Is their self-assumed
divine right to set a precedent
for others? This practice, if it
becomes widespread, would undermine the D.S.R.C., remove all
student control of it, and set up
another independent inquisition
at the Homewood. What safeguards exist in the D.S.R.C. constitution must be preserved, or
the threat of proctors in the entries will become a reality.

Strong Sees Two Month Delay
Due To Season's First Storm
(Continued from page 7)
and his technical crew have been
working on the telescope every
night, testing every detail of this
complex telescope to assure
tl--nnselves that it can do the
job for which it will be launched.
Critical Step
On November 8 Dr. Strong
was willing to have it moved
from the trailer. At ten a.m, a
crew lowered a wooden cradle
into the trailer from the giant
hook of a fifty foot crane. When
the cradle was securely bound to
the telescope, the crane operator
started to pull the telescope upward, inch by inch. A half hour
later the telescope was swung
free of the trailer and slowly
moved over fifteen feet where
it hung directly over the top
hatch of the gondola.
Foul* technicians stood on a
wooden platform surrounding
the gondola guiding the tubular
end of the telescope as it was
again inch by inch lowered into
the gondola. Three men were
Inside the gondola to guide it to
fts lower mounting as it slipped
lower toward the gondola floor.

HELD OVER!

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOV. 21, 1958 Ho

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE FOURTEEN

As still' cameramen, motion
picture operators and newsmen
recorded the action they joined
the technical crew in hardly
breathing while this, one of the
most important pre-flight activities took place. Dr. Strong stood
by in his flaming red wool shirt,
pulling on his ever-present pipe,
watching expressionless as the
telescope was moved.
One strong jerk by the crane,
or the breaking of any part
of the cradle could have spelled
disaster for this historic project.
One can call this a truly historic flight because it will be
the first time a human being
has risen to a height where he
is above 97% of the earth's atmosphere to get an unobstructed
view of a planet. Dr. Strong said
today that if successful he will
see Mars better than he could
with the 200-inch telescope at
Mt. Palomar.

At 12:35 the telescope was
bolted to the floor of the gondola—safely.
During the next few days Di.
Strong will test the telescope
from within the gondola; will
spend two seven hour periods inside the gondola with Commander Malcolm D. Ross from whom
Strong will receive indoctrination in everything to be done
during the flight. Commander
Ross'is one of the world's best
balloon pilots, having made three
record breaking ascents in this
gondola, which was originally
designed in 1946 by Jean Piccard, brother of Auguste Piccard
who made the first flight into
the stratosphere.
Thin Yellow Suits Supplied
While
being
indoctrinated
both Strong and Ross will wear
their pressure suits, pressurized
masks and helmets. Over the

pressure suit they will wear arctic
weather jackets and another suit
of thin, yellow material. At top
altitude during the night of the
flight the temperature inside the
gondola will be aproximately 20
degrees above zero, and may
drop lower.
Today Commander Ross said
they will take coffee, water,
candy bars, and sandwiches
wrapped in sealed plastic containers for food on this 24-hour

• At 2:00 p.m. they will be taken
to the gondola where they will
sit on the nylon webbing seats
and begin their pre-flight operations. At 2:15 p.m. the entrance
hatch will be sealed from within
the gondola.
At one p.m. the 300-ft.-long
plastic balloon will begin to he
inflated from long helium tanks.
By 3 p.m. the balloon should be
one-fifth inflated. Full inflation
will take place as the helium
expands during the ascent to
80,000 feet. At top altitude the
balloon will expand to 2-million
cubic feet, an a diameter of
173 feet.
Set Free
At approximately 3:15 the balloon will be set free from the
floor 500 feet below the rim of
the Strato-Bowl.
If good winds prevail the
balloon and gondola should land
somewhere within a 200 mile
radius of Chicago.

Electrodes Too!
On launch day Strong and
Ross will be taken to a readyshack at approximately 1:00 p.m.
wheer Captain Norman L. Barr,
medical director for the flight,
will tape electrodes to various
parts of their bodies. These
electrodes will be plugged into a
tiny radio sending set, the size
of a package of cigarettes. This
will send back to Dr. Barr, flying in his airplane, information
on the rate of their breathing,
heart beat, skin temperature and
several other bits of information about their reaction. After
this they will don their flying
gear.

The launch was expected to
have taken place on Thursdah
November 13, weather permitting. Sunny skies and no breeze
were needed for a perfect launch.

Jay Junior Jocks Dribblers Make Beall
Cap Grid Careers For Towson Opening
By JOE FERRANTE
The Johns Hopkins freshman
football squad closed out a
"highly successful season" last
week, finishing the season at
Gettysburg with a 3-1 record.
Coach Bob Scott lauded his
boys, saying, "This team accomplished more with its physical ability than any other frosh
team I've ever handled here.
Despite its limited experience,
only 17 of the 36 on the team
had ever played before, the team
really came through."
At Gettysburg, the junior Birdmen displayed an excellent team
effort against a school whose
football is in a bit faster league
than is Hopkins.
The Jays dominated play for
most of the first half, taking an
8-0 lead, with their score coming
on a. three yard plunge by fullback Phil Sutley, whose rushing,
93 yards on 21 carries, kept the
offense moving. The extra points
were added by virtue of a Powellto-Sutley pass.Gettysburg evened
the score in the last 45 seconds
of the half on a fourteen yard
TD-pass.
Impressive Stands
During the second half, the
Gettysburg team controlled the
ball most of the time, but were
held from scoring by two impressive goal-line stands on the part
of the Hopkins defensive line..
After the second stand, the
Blue Jay frosh began to move
with the ball. Highlighted by the
brutal running of Sutley, the
Jays brought the ball to their
30-yard line. There they fumbled. G-Burg took the pigskin
and, after three unsuccessful
scoring attempts, hit pay dirt
with a fourth down pass. The
conversion was missed.
Desperation passes by the Blue
Jay frosh were to no avail, and
the clock ran out with the score
at 14-8, in favor of Gettysburg.
As far as the season's performance is concerned, the team
received good mileage from quarterbacks Billy Powell and Joe
Cioni, halfbacks Henry Ciccarone
and Bill Flannery and, fullbacks
Bob Homlar and Phil Sutley,
Statistics And Squad
Ciccarone, Flannery, Homlar
and Sutley each averaged over

we've

3.5 yards a carry on the ground.
Cioni, Powell, and Ciccarone
sparked the passing offense, with
Ciccarone tossing three TD passes, of 35, 46 and 46 yards, to end
Terry Weltman. Cioni and Powell threw several passes to end
Jerry Schmidt for large gains.
Rounding out the backfield
were Don Layne, Derwin Kim,
Joe Dornbush, Tim Parmley,
Frank Hussey, Don Haynie and
Roland Blantz,
Coach Scott had great praise
for his defensive line, which held
the opposition to an average of
80 yards rushing per game. The
line was mainly composed of ends
Weltman and Schmidt; tackles
John Becker, Buff Ward and
John Doud; guards Dale Steiger,
Dave Rowe and Dick Hoover and
center Pat Boyer.
Backing up the starting ends
were Roger Peterson, George
Zaiser, Bob Raub and Al Shevach. Completing the tackle
corps were Don- Steiner, Bill
Westerkam and Stan Levine.
"Valuable Addition"
Other guards who saw action
were Jon Hayes, the team's punting specialist who averaged 39.5
yards on ten punts, Ted Hartka,
Lee Hollein, Dick King, Doug
Kushnir and Roy Mayne. Lou
Svoboda, who subbed at center,
also showed much improvement.
Coach Scott emphasized that
Duane Levine, a chemical engineering grad student and former Hopkins player, who was responsible for the backfield play,
was a "great help to me and the
team." Also, George Cooke, Wilfred Fujimoto, and Clarence Nagao, managers, gave the team a
hard working staff.
In summing up his views on
this year's frosh football squad,
the coach stated that "they will
be a valuable addition to the
varsity squad next Year. I feel
sure that they will be able to
make the switch to single-wing
play."

Tall Blue Jay BB Team Boasts Seven Seniors, Many Top Lowerclassnn
Coach Expects Additional Strength After End Of Soccer Season
By PAUL MUSICANT
Currently preparing for its
first battle of the season is the
Hopkins varsity basketball team,
under the direction of Coach
Ross Sachs. A fairly experienced
team has given the Jays an
optimistic outlook for the season, although it is still too early
for Coach Sachs to predict any
final outcome of success.
Seven seniors are among the
13 players currently being carried on the team. Leading this
year's Jay Hoopsters will be cocaptains Dick Weinstein and Bill
Berndt.
Other promising players include Larry Becker, Bill DeVoe,
Peter Greenberg, Malcolm Levine and Chuck Laughran. All of
these played basketball last year
for Hopkins, and are expected
to play an important part in
the team's performance.
Returning after a year's absence are Bill Morrill, Ed Bernstein and Sheldon Wollman,
while sophomores up from last
year's frosh include Dave Weinstein and Al Moyer. Coach Sachs
also expects Larry Ey to come
out, af r soccer season concludes tomorrow. Present expectations see no further players
coming out from either the football or soccer teams.

H. James Cornelius graduated from
Swarthmore College in 1954 with a B.S.
in Electrical Engineering: He's been
"growing" ever since with the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania.
After an initial 44-week inter-departmental training course, Jim was made
Facility Engineer in charge of the fastgrowing Norristown-Pottstown area. In
that capacity, he engineered over half a
million dollars' worth of carrier systems
and cable facilities between major switching centers.
Today, he is one of 50 young engineers
from the Bell Telephone Companies
chosen to attend a special Operating
Engineers Training Program at Bell Lab-

oratories. This 19-month course of study
—with full pay—deals with advanced
techniques and new concepts in electronics which signal a-new era in telephony. It involves both classroom theory
and practical laboratory applications.
When Jim and his colleagues return to
their companies, they'll review major
engineering projects. This will assure
the best use of equipment for current
engineering, as well as for expected new
developments in communications.
"I wanted a job I could grow with,"
says Jim, "and I've got it. I can't think
of a better place than the telephone company for an engineering graduate to find
a promising future."

Many young men like Jim Cornelius are finding rewarding careers with the Bell Telephone Companies.
Look into opportunities for you. Talk with the Bell
interviewer when he visits your campus. And read the
Bell Telephone booklet on file in your Placement Office.

Garcia skirts left end to pick
up more yardage against Dickinson. The Jays' win last Saturday enabled them to maintain
their top position in the Southern Division of the Middle-Atlantic Conference. A victory, tomorrow will clinch the title.
Hopkins' strength last Saturday
was in their ground game, where
they gained 217 yards, and in
their defensive line, which held
the Red Devils to a mere 89
yards rushing. The Jays only big
weakness was their pass defense
which allowed Dickinson to complete 12 of 23. The rain favored
the Blue Jays.

TOUCH.DOWN
Russ Martenson sprints for an
Oz Garcia aerial for a Jay touchdown against the Red Devils
last Saturday. Hopkins overcame
a first quarter 3-0 lead of the
Devils to remain undefeated in
the Southern Division of the
Middle-Atlantic Conference. The
Blue Jays journey to Westminster tomorrow seeking a fourth
consecutive conquest of their
arch rival. Should the Jays be
successful in their encounter
with the Green Terrors, they
will gain the championship of
the Southern College Division of
the M-A Conference. Thus far
Hopkins is 5-0 in league competition and 5-2 overall. The two
losses were to Mason-Dixon foes,
Ranand
Hampden-Sydney
dolph-Macon.
